reviewText:
This is a good first attempt. But in no way sufficient.

The technical aspect is clearly lackluster. The game doesn't have a fast forward, history or auto-read. I makes subsequent playthrough a bit annoying.
And no, unity is not designed for a visual novel. I know that some things are easier to do with it than with a game engine like Ren'Py, but the constraint are quite annoying : 200MB of ram ? really ? 64b system only ? Visual novels are great being played on small factor devices. For these reason, this is not possible with this game.

Characters art are good. However, they could benefit from more movements and poses.
Some special scenes (like the one in the shower room) could have dedicated graphics.
Some art are a bit behind in term of quality, like the shopping scene or the beach one. This is acceptable on a first try. But only on a first try.

Character development is... poor. Sorry, but that's something to work on.

Story is short, so i know i should not expect a great scenario.
As for the writing. Please note that descriptions are not superfluous. It does not have to be only dialogue.

This is a good test (on the developper's perspective) for things that are related to a game, like monetisation and deployment.

But remember, experience is merely the name men gave to their mistakes.
voteText: 203 of 235 people (86%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
A mediocre visual novel in which a well-endowed Mary Sue gets to fall in love with the character of her dreams. Literally. Granted, I wasn't expecting a literary masterpiece (who was?); decent yuri fluff would have been more than enough to justify the price tag.

But let's be honest here: 'mediocre' gives A Wild Catgirl Appears! far more credit than it deserves. Even if you can somehow get over the middle school-grade writing skill and all its typographical errors, the game itself is flawed at a mechanical level to a baffling degree; the menu is out of an alpha stage demo, background quality is inconsistent, the CGs border on nightmare fuel, sprites aren't always scaled properly and the painfully stock music often fails to queue as intended.

Then again, what do you expect from a VN made in Unity? No, I'm not kidding, it's actually built in Unity. Who the ♥♥♥♥ does that when options like Ren'Py exist?! I struggle to think of anything more blatantly amateur.

'Amateur' -- that's the lesson today. Character sprites this nice deserved better. Much better. Stick with the works of Hanako, Ebi-hime, Christine Love or even Sakura Fantasy if you want a competent OEL yuri VN; you're not going to find one here.

In conclusion: This game is terrible. I wouldn't recommend it even to my worst enemy. But it has cards and only 4 achievements for easy completion so... It's something ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

reviewText:
A Wild Catgirl Appears is a really short - and not very well done - visual novel with a centering theme on female homosexuality. Yup, this is a Yuri title. I would really like to recommend this game, considering there aren't many otome visual novels that would even include same sex romance options and a game focusing on female homosexuality sounds like a concept to be supported - if only it would be better executed and accurately presented. Yet, the execution of the theme is really poor here, both with the boring narrative and non-existent character depth. It is just not a good game.

Here we have Ami, a shy and nerdy teenage girl who attends an all-female high school, alongside her best friend Ria. Her parents travel throughout the year to attend business meetings, so Ami has all the time and the space in the world to herself, and she is lonely. Stating a useful fact on the side: she is also gay and faces the fear of being judged if she were to come out of the closet. To keep herself busy, she decides to attend the Coding Club of the school and start working on a platform video game that they'd make with the senior club president, Lise. At some point, the designed protagonist of the game; a ninja cat girl named Starla comes alive, mostly to Ami's surprise and distress. How to handle this situation now?

Let's start with the display quality, shall we? There is an annoying inconsistency about the artworks and the CGs used for characters. Throughout my full playthrough, I've came across 4 different types of art works depicting the same characters ridiculously differently - none being appeasing or even anatomically correct. There has been some sorry attempts at presenting fan service, but no one should specifically prefer these ones for even that purpose. Environment designs are nothing remarkable or even remotely interesting, and the soundtrack is only forgettable. Oh, and there is no voice acting either.

I wouldn't care much for the art quality if only there were to be somewhat decent narrative and an intriguing storyline. Well, there is none! The storyline doesn't carry any drama, mystery, insight, sentimental attachment or anything that would make Ami's story interesting. She - alongside four romance options - and her ordeal, her frustration is presented as shallow as it can be. There is no credible story progression, no real life solution to the subject matter or a character portrayal that would make us emphasize with Ami. Character interactions are downright boring, with superficial social exchanges playing on the idea of female sexuality. Whomever wrote that script, clearly had no idea about an actual female/female relationship. The developer only established a sorry setting to play on some fantasy here and earn some money from it while he is at it. Aside portraying wholly shallow characters, the narrative is full with grammatical errors and dialogues marked for wrong characters. Without any option to reread the dialogue once its passed, it becomes a problem to keep track of whomever said what, and without much you'd be curious about the story itself, you lose interest fast.

To top all the nonsense this game contains, save game function is completely broken. If it's a Win64, sorry people. You cannot save at all. Developers are trying to solve that problem at the moment, but it seems like a problem with the game engine itself, so... no near future solutions yet. At least there is a skip dialogue option to go for fast playthroughs to achievement hunt.

At the end of the day, you may prefer passing this one. There is nothing intriguing or esthetically pleasing here. Even people who'd buy this to take a glimpse on some girl on girl action could probably do with something else better. Sad story.

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Not really.... the best.

I want to be able to give a better review; the game is, in its own way, charming. And the characters are pretty cute. However, there are just too many things that let the game down. I've heard from other reviews that it was made in only a month, but I feel that that still doesn't excuse some of its issues.

The first thing I'll mention is the artwork. Some character shots are okay, whilst a lot of others are of pretty shockingly poor quality. Some simply show a poor grasp on anatomy (and not in the way of over-large boobs, as thats of course a style all of its own - more in the way of strangely twisted frames and limbs), whilst other genuinly look as though they've been edited in a couple of minutes in paints - like the originals, but with features altered or added with thick, black blurry lines. Other images seem to be have been scaled up and down strangely, whilst some of the backgrounds are of dramatically better quality than others.

The outcome seems difficult to control, and the ending abrupt. Theres also very little in the way of actual romance scenes, though I only played through once, so there may be more hidden in there (though I doubt it). I was offered very little lesbain cat-girl smut, but to futher cement things I was also offered very little in the way of romantic story, and so walked away from the game pretty unhappy in general.

What else is there to say? Buttons are unresponsive, and take some trial and error to find - they're no where near their graphics. There is very little in the way of controls, with the game lacking even a basic volume control.

In conclussion, it is after all a pretty cheap game, even cheaper when on sale, and some may be able to look past its numerous faults in order to appreciate some hidden charms. If you're not new to visual novels, as I am, and are more willing to forgive, then give it a go. If not, I'd recommend passing it by.

reviewText:
We're told that Ami the main character is awkward but her dialogue is probably the most normal between her and her best friend Ria, who has to call Ami stupid every few lines. Not that she's some sort of Tsundere or anything... Baka...

There's also a weird line where Ami asks Ria not to add to the mocking that she already gets. Literally none. No one apart from Ria ever gives her a hard time.

There's also Lise, who's talent and natural gifts apparently knows no bounds. I can write off her ability to make 3D models in a night because I can assume that she's both talented and doesn't leave the school to go home at any point, but I can't ignore the fact that she and Ami make their own Intendo based chip-containing figure which is able to give players various rewards in the game they decide to make.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B58EH-nNbq8

Main menu is badly scaled along with the font, all the characters are off center, the dialogue box is cut off, when making a desicion, the buttons aren't calibrated and the bonus art screen is just... I took ten tries for me to go back to the main menu before it was required to alt tab and just restart the game. It looks like the port from iPhone was made and nothing was rescaled.

Plenty of scenes that can be cut and therefore slows the pacing for no reason. Any interesting points about Ami trying to come out of closet or her loneliness due to her parents all but abandoning her, is either brushed off or just isn't developed to a convincing agree.

It's the first game by NewWest but only so much can be ignored and attributed to inexperience versus just a bad game and story.

reviewText:
有心的開發者，值得好評。English available below
Pixnet[singht.pixnet.net]、Keylol評測[www.keylol.com]
A Wild Catgirl Appears!是款視覺小說遊戲，女主角Ami是一名百合宅女。
遊戲可選四條主線，分別是Ria、Lise、Eiko和Starla。

Ria 黑長直傲嬌委員長，我第一條線便是主攻Ria。
(因為Ami顧著幫部裡畫畫而稍微冷落了Ria，直接衝到Lise面前宣示主權:Ami是我的！喔喔喔)

Lise 金髮編程部部長
剛認識Lise借了部遊戲給Ami，女主角是可以控制時間同逆轉重選...心想:Life is strange??

貓女Starla
她是Lise同Ami打算創作遊戲中的女主角，Ami手下畫出的人物。

貓女Eiko
無原無故跳出來的角色，在Starla出現後突然提到她的存在。至少Starla有個3D手辦弄出來的交代…

故事情節乏味，故事展開前其實還好，心裡滿滿的期待感。

豈料貓女出現後就急轉直下...不提遊戲中沒有快轉、對話記錄、自動跳轉等基本功能，視覺小說類遊戲可玩時數居然20分鐘可以玩完一條線！內容嚴重不足，更別說情節牽強，關係發展過於突兀。CG也不是特別美，主要畫風不合我合味=.=

基本上Ria、Lise跟Starla線情節一模一樣，差別只是在於選擇後的兩三句回應。
最火大的是Ria跟Lise線最後找Starla說話與內容相差無幾，人物不同而已。
Eiko線我是最後才玩，發現找完Starla竟然有後續，但亦多了3-4分鐘罷了。

另外所謂的隱藏成就，只需要完成4條路線便解開了，一個Ending一個成就。

14號開發者公告說知道很多人投訴有各類bug、沒快轉功能之類的，開發者承諾近期內放出免費更新。更新包括修復bug、新增快轉、添加故事情節和人物背景。

本來已經想給負評...現在姑且等更新後再決定
=======
2月25號更新︰
昨天24號開發者發佈了補丁，終於可以給評分了。
好評一個，相信有心的開發者會將遊戲改得愈來愈好。

首先十分欣賞開發者對遊戲的用心，針對評論作出修正，但當中仍有改善的地方。
再次玩AWCG發現，對話中女主角Ami不再出現。然而去到CG，真心給dev點個讚，Ami變美了很多。優質日式畫風，我喜歡。
小驚喜居然有一個新加的成就，雖然遊戲初頭就能直接取得。

針對新版本的測評

優點︰
圖像如背景、介面等的優化
新添加和比舊版本豐富的內容
優質CG！完爆舊版馬虎草圖
缺點︰
舊版好像有同樣問題，心裡話"和"說話"沒明顯的介定，只能從內容分辨
跳轉功能不好用。理想中的是按住"Ctrl"跳轉，鬆開就停止。但AWCG要點擊"Skip"按鈕開始跳轉，停止需要在按鈕外點一下(汗
無CG畫廊
仍然無對話歷史
可以改善的地方︰
添加Q.Save聲響，經常懷疑有沒有成功儲存
右鍵開設置畫面，現在儲存/載入都要移到右下角點設置...麻煩
每當過渡音樂就會突然斷掉，可以修改得更為暢順
Dev serious about the game

reviewText:
My full review can be found here.[www.the-backlog.net]

A Wild Catgirl Appears! follows the story of high schooler Ami as she is forced to join a club. While creating a game featuring a ninja catgirl, the catgirl figure (basically an Amiibo) comes to life and starts living with her. You'll be able to go down one of four romance paths in this fairly short visual novel.

A Wild Catgirl Appears! features some of the most clashing art I've ever seen. Some CG images are very clearly done by two different artists, often with parts of their regular" model pasted onto the body of some MS Paint drawing. The internal resolution also seems to be no where near what the resolutions you can set the game at
date: causing a lot of pixelation in both the images and the menus.\n\nThere's not much notable about the story besides there suddenly just being catgirls. You can't scroll back through the dialogue at all either
recommended: as A Wild Catgirl Appears! lacks certain basic functions every other VN I've read has had - a backlog. There's also no way to fast forward through previously read text
hoursPlayed: meaning if you want to get all the paths
voteText: you'll have to click through it manually.\n\nThere's not much in the way to really recommend about this game. There are much better VN's out there. So save your money and just look elsewhere
helpfulPercent: even if you are into the whole catgirl thing."
commentsCount: 17 of 22 people (77%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I really like the Visual Novel genre, which is why I can be really critical of it. And it pains me when I come across games like this that will turn people off to it before they get to any of the good stuff.

I think the dev's heart was in the right place, as it's clear that he or she has played games like this before. And while the art style is Western, there are clear anime and general Japanese influences on the setting and some of the characters. But the art is just not very good, and the writing is incredibly weak. There's nothing interesting about any of these characters and the humor falls flat every time. The best that can be said is that it does take the difficulty of a same-sex relationship somewhat seriously. The music is better off muted, especially the time-of-day transition tune which fills me with rage.

Another issue is that whatever program this was made in (I've seen it before) has an awful UI. I'm guessing it's a free or low cost VN creator. There is extremely limited functionality for the player, and it seems to miss some clicks as well when in the save and load screen. You do get achievements and five endings which is a plus if you like the game. (Note: I'm not sure what the true play time of this was due to trading card idling but it's fairly short for each run).

I'd avoid this one or at least don't get your hopes up too high for it if you get it from a bundle.

reviewText:
I think my biggest problem with A Wild Catgirl Appears! is that the art styles are so vastly different at points that it throws me for a loop. Or maybe it's the dialogue? Or maybe it's the story line...

Either way, I got this game in a bundle for under a buck and I still feel as though it wasn't a particularly good use of my time. It took me two hours to get all the achievements (only because I did read through one path in totality before giving up and using the oh-so-helpful skip button) and two hours for the rest of the card drops. After that, I'll never boot this game up again--why would I?

Let's break this attempt at a visual novel down, shall we?

.Characters.
Japanese school girls who attend an all-girls school and have very little parental supervision for one reason or another. That about sums them up. One is moe, one is shy, one is a ninja, and one is a ninja student. And then there's you, the loner main character. The cast is very generic to the genre.

.Story.
You and a classmate are creating a game in a coding club after school. An after school club that has no members yet somehow has the funding to make RIF figures for a fully-functioning game that you create in a couple of sittings. Right. Your main character, Ami, takes the newly-made figure home and, lo-and-behold, you have a living, breathing cat girl and her cat girl friend that inexplicably accompanies her right in the comfort of your room. Ta-dah! And, for our next trick, the game makes these catgirls fit into society just like everyone else while your main character struggles to figure out which classmate or catgirl she'd like to date most.

The time frame of the game is very slippery. It feels as though the events, particularly the conclusion, just sort of bluster by as though the devs don't want you to think too hard about the logictics behind them.

Inexplicable" is the key word for this game. There's a lot that doesn't get adequately described
date: but you're just kind of expected to accept things--much in the way that the characters do. No one questions the appearance of the titular "wild catgirl" and no one even seems to care that a half-naked girl wearing cat ears is wandering around among the general public. Ah
recommended: Japan.\n\nBut back to the story: the catgirl

Which brings us to our next point.

.Voice acting and dialogue.
Most of it was irritating. Abrasive

If you're a card and achievement collector

reviewText:
I can't call this visual novel a good one, when it doesn't even feel like a finished one.

First the positives
+the character art is pretty good
+the music is okay
+the story is sweet

overall I didn't feel like A Wild Catgirl Appears was a waste of time, but there were many things that just didn't play right so here goes

-there's no log, so you can't review what you're answering if you load a save
-skipping doesn't stop after a choice is made. If you skip to a choice to see the other option, you miss the first few sentences anyway, since the game doesn't let you go back.
-there is no option to end the game. That's. That's basic stuff.
-certain dialogues are attributed to the wrong character
-it's often unclear whether a character is saying something or just thinking it

and that's just from the actual gameplay experience, not just a personal opinion or preference. I do have those too though.

-the plot is completely unexplained and often nonsensical
-what were even those pixellated scene transitions please find a better font
-the references are lackluster at best
-bad pacing that spends most of the time on the beginning setting things up, and then there's no time used for actually experiencing them
-the characters manage to avoid being completely stereotypical, but still fall straight into boring

I didn't drop the game, but there are many better VNs you can find, if you want to spend your money on dating sims.

Does it run perfectly, or have all the issues been fixed? No. There are also things that can't be changed - such as the game itself in terms of characters, the story, etc.

reviewText:
You know, one of the greatest video game gimmicks that ever was devised is that of the toy figure that can interact with your games. Skylanders started it, and then Nintendo went and made the Amiibo figures that work with lots of different games like Super Smash Bros. Wii, and others. Then Disney got it and just ran with it- now you can find pretty much every Disney property in its own game, Infinity. Why, one of these days, you'll be able to buy a 3D printer program and RFID chip and just make your own. ...though what would you do if the RFID chip decided to not work, but even crazier, it suddenly changed into the very catgirl ninja you were coding into the game? Such is the idea behind A Wild Catgirl Appears .

You play as Ami, a high-school student in a Japanese girls school who's suddenly faced with a bit of a problem- the student council has handed down a decision- this year, every student has to join a club. This presents a bit of a problem- Ami's not that much of an athlete, and not that popular, so well... she ends up joining the school's coding club. There, she meets another person- another girl by the name of Lise, and they start working on a game, one that stars a catgirl ninja, named Starla. One day, Lise gets the idea to make an Amiibo-style figure of Starla. The figure doesn't work, but... the next day, Ami finds a surprise in her bed- one catgirl ninja who has no idea how she got there... yeah, that's pretty much the story.

I'll say it right now- this is a VN with a yuri twist to it. Ami has the chance to end up with one of four different girls- Ria (the best friend), Lise (the coding club president), Starla (the catgirl ninja), and Eiko (another catgirl that just... appeared somehow).

The story, well... it leaves a lot to be desired. There are many errors in spelling and grammar that need to be corrected that ought to have been caught with a quick spellcheck and a read-through. Not to mention, the introduction of Eiko is handled really poorly- she just shows up out of nowhere with no major event or anything. It just sticks out that she's just there- she just shows up and is just there to be another possible love interest. Why not flesh them out a bit? It needs to be polished up, and there needs to be a reason as to why Eiko shows up other than Oh
date: have some free DLC!"\n\nThe art is good- I just wish there was more of it. Almost every character picture is the exact same pose- and 90% of them are the same but with just the facial expressions changed. The backgrounds look nice
recommended: but more are needed- you can't pass off a pool locker room as a clothing store changing room
hoursPlayed: for example. Throw in some variety
voteText: throw in some new poses
helpfulPercent: and suddenly you have more variety and better understanding of the characters. There is a bit of skin
votesHelpful: and it does imply a lot of stuff
votesTotal: but... I think this is another of those that ended up having material cut to get itself on Steam.\n\nHowever
commentsCount: glaring error in this game- there are four different endings
column16: and you can get any of them. However
column18: you need to close and re-launch the game to clear the event flags in order to get a different ending- if you play through the game a second time
column19: you still get the first ending you got. I am rather surprised this wasn't addressed in the re-release. It's a glaring error that ought to have been smashed out somehow.\n\nLet's get down to brass tacks

column21: and it could honestly benefit from plenty of TLC from its artists

reviewText:
To start out this review, I'm going to go ahead and say that I'm a dude who really appreciates kind of shoddy/nonsense VNs, so when I saw this game appear on the front page of Steam the day after the Holiday sale for about as much money as I had in my Steam Wallet, I was in. I went in with no expectations or desires, and that was definitely beneficial to the experience.

This game is just very innocent, like an 8 year old's journal entry except with a little bit more cleavage. The writing looks like the authors used only the 100 most frequently used words in English, so it's very easy and fast to read. This honestly would be a pretty good game for someone learning English as a second language. They go to a mall! A beach! A cafe! It reminds me of a Spanish 102 lesson, and it kept my attention more than a Spanish 102 lesson because it had anime cat girls with big boobs in it.

Speaking of anime cat girls with big boobs, the art in this game is kind of a mixed bag. The standard character illustrations that you'll see the most of are quite nicely drawn, and they have enough different facial expressions to keep things fairly interesting. The backgrounds are fine, not overly blurry like some cheap VNs, and establish the setting of the game well enough. One thing that kind of took away from the graphics was the fact that I played it at the maximum available resolution (1600x1200) and the graphics looked to be scaled up to meet that resolution, which made them kind of blurred/pixelated. That resolution shouldn't be an option if it's just going to scale up and look terrible. I would rather have had a smaller window with sharp graphics than a large one with blurry graphics.

When the art starts to fall apart is when the characters go off model from their standard illustrations. If a character is posed differently, their proportions become odd, their bodies or heads become chibi-fied in kind of a rough way, or they become pretty noodly and strange. It's very jarring to have a nicely illustrated and detailed character become a wiggly mess just because they needed a different pose, but it happens. Still, I was kind of charmed by this, so I'll totally let it slide. It made the whole thing seem like a high school project.

The writing in this game is fine for an anime catgirl VN. It probably would have taken away from the experience to have this thing read like a good, detailed book, so its relatively simplistic plotline and treatment thereof contributed to this game being a fairly easygoing time. The main character is a closeted high school lesbian, which is pretty cool, and most of the tension with the non-catgirl characters that arises from this made it fairly interesting. It also was a nice stark contrast to see how the catgirls didn't really care about sexual orientation, which further separated them from the realm of the real. The game's inclusion of catgirls and non-catgirls to romance (or friend-mance? There wasn't a terrible amount of romance in this, honestly) made things interesting, although I ended up getting all the catgirl endings first because of my natural inclinations.

Finally, the music in this game was surprisingly pleasant. It was incidental and non-obtrusive. There were some fairly long stretches of the game that did not have any background music, which was disappointing, but the music that was there was well made and fit the game very well. I particularly liked the chiptune song that played over the credits.

Overall, I don't think anyone who is considering this game is expecting this to be an edge-of-your-seat, tour-de-force emotional rollercoaster (although there is a physical rollercoaster in this game). A lot of the negative reviews seem to be knee-jerk reactions to the relatively shoddy quality of the game, and that's fair. But if you're looking for a quick and innocent little game that expects nothing from you, then this is worth the three dollars that these devs are asking.

reviewText:
**This game just barely get a recommendation**

This game is an anime visual novel. An 18 year old high school girl joins the Coding Club at School.   She uses her talents to draw artwork for a video game the club is making starring a ninja catgirl.   In a twist of events the catgirl comes to life and lives with the main character.

This game is almost a good game but is held back by being unpolished in terms of story and uneven artwork.   The reason I'm giving the game a thumbs up is that the developer has openly acknowleged the flaws and is working to fix them.   If these problems get fixed then this game goes from average to good.

reviewText:
Short game with strange pacing. Game lasts about 50 mins. About 60% of that is the beginning, 30% the middle, and the last 10% makes up the incredibly rushed ending.

The game is front loaded with a lot of pop culture references. That, combined with the rushed ending, makes me think that someone wrote the beginning in a single sitting beause they had the idea for the game, and then when they went back to it they didn't really know where to take it. That's my only explanation, aside from that maybe different people wrote different sections and it didn't come together as well as they'd hoped.

The new art is nice (just happened to play this game on the day the update was released), but the proportions are a bit off.

Lastly, I have to ask...what the hell is going on? How is it possible that on three separate runs, I keep ending up with Eiko? While choosing completely different choices each time? Is it a glitch in the new version? I mean, these types of games are essentially flow charts. Is Eiko like Rome, in that all roads lead to her and her brand new apartment? If that's the case, then what are those secret achievements? Have I ever told you the definition of insanity!? (See, I can do it too)

reviewText:
Okay... so I knew this game a while back since it was out on itch.io. I believe it came out 2 month ago. I really didn't have the chance to buy it till now.

The game has it's charm. The characters are alright... It has Tsundere, Nerdy girl with HUGE chest, Animu girl (protagonist), and Catgirls. It's alright I guess.

The main issue I should say would be the drawing! Some drawing are alright, but when it comes to full CG, I don't know if the artist changed or quit helping the game, the drawing is totally different from the character's image. Like someone cut the character's face and draw a body under it... It's really gross to be honest and kind of a let down... I wish they used the same artist or find an artist that can draw similar to the original one.

I do not want to give a thumbs down yet since I haven't finished the game. But once I finish it, I'll give more full review. Until then, I will give this a Thumbs up for now...

If anyone want to check a little preview, come check it out.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=54nIHK64n10

reviewText:
From playing the game for a little while so far, here are my thoughts.

The game is simple, with the bare minimal to work as a visual novel.
The UI could use a lot of polishing/work to look cleaner and more consistent.
The 3 save slots could definitely be increased. There aren't too many choices but its better to have more slave slots then not enough. The character art looks solid, especially for what looks like the first release by this group (person?), but the backgrounds and variation of artwork could be improved. Text skips should also be included, so we don't have to wait for the sentences to fully scroll before continuing. There are also occasional hiccups with artwork being incorrectly displayed for a few frames.

The story isn't too bad, though I have yet to finish it. The characters are all pretty distinctive, and play on many cliches and tropes. There are also a lot of references to the real world. (Intendo, Fire Shield, etc) It is amusing, and doesn't take itself seriously at all. The music is decent as well, though a little repetitive.

The game is just three dollars though, and the store page screenshots pretty much show exactly what you're going to get, at this price I can say I feel like you could do a lot worse. Plus, this game has catgirls.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s09tCq2PJQA

This review is spoilerless.

A Wild Catgirl is a short Visual Novel game in which you're a girl called Ami who suffers with low levels of self esteem, you go through the struggles of her being attracted to her same gender but being unable to come out of the closet for a while. Your best friend Ria introduces you into a hobby after school class in where you meet another girl who teaches coding. You make a character and she comes to life. So now you have all these different girls all craving attention.

The game plays very linear with only very few choices to make which are pretty simple ones.

Positives:
+ Cheap
+ Funny plot
+ Achievements and badges

Negatives:
- It would be good if there was spacebar to go to next text as mouse clicking is harder for me with my setup
- Artwork can get very rough at times and feel very out of place
- Lack of variety in the backdrops
- No sound sliders to adjust audio levels
- Lack of story decisions, you feel like you're reading more often than not
- Very minimal in terms of character interactions with others than the main characters and no cute boys

I myself enjoyed this game, apart from the abudance of negatives most are easily overlooked if you're looking for a very simple VN. It's a very cheap game and a fun one at that, the story is pretty wild and unbelievable and that's what I like about it.

I would recommend it to gamers who are looking for a cheap and fun blast on a romance visual novel as long as you are not expecting too much. I would also recommend it to badge and achievement hunters as they are easy to stack up and obtain. A full playthrough takes around 1.5 hours.

I would not recommend it to gamers who expect a higher quality game; this is not it. The plot is not that deep and is quite wacky. The graphics are also not the best meaning if you care for graphics in a visual novel you will more than likely dislike this game. I would also avoid if you like making a lot of choices in VN's because this VN simply falls way short of that bar with only very minimal choices.

Score: Buy it

I wouldn't reccomend wasting your money on this and I normally love anime visual novel games. Sorry! :(

reviewText:
I don't know, man.

That's pretty much my answer to all questions regarding this.. visual novel. I'm a big fan of visual novels, and so I can judge fairly harsh. This is by no means a professional review, it's just my thoughts on the matter. But I'll give it in simple terms:

Pros:
- Decent character art.
- Decent background art.
- Decent music

Cons:
- Short (can be considered a pro if you hate it)
- Weak characters
- Weak plot

Basically, in my own opinion, this is a very bad visual novel. I can see effort was put into this, but.. it just doesn't hold up in the end.  I won't even go into the options.. or rather, the serious lack of them.
I may very well dislike this visual novel because I prefer long and in-depth stories, with a lot of character development. I think that's only natural. This just doesn't feel right, whatsoever. Ahh, opinions, don't we love 'em? Anyway, if you're going for all achievements, or just want to do all routes, you better start using the skip option. The story is identical except for a few different lines - regardless of the option you choose. After a few lines of new" dialogue it goes right back onto the same story as if your choice didn't matter. The only significance your choices have are.. let's just say
date: you get a point for a girl if you choose the "correct" option. Whatever girl you have the most points with in the end
recommended: you'll end up with.\nAll that being said
hoursPlayed: it's all good if you like simple
voteText: short stories and yuri romance.\n\nTL;DR: If you like a simple story with some romance and girl on (cat)girl action
helpfulPercent: give it a go. If not

reviewText: Cute premise but poor follow through. Very buggy, poorly mixed art, and loads of text issues.

reviewText: The game is funny. I love Starla and Eiko, but I love catgirls, even when they\'re naive.  The game does have some text issues that need to be fixed.  Sometimes words are missing in sentences, words are mispelled, or the wrong name is up for the speaker.  Overall, it\'s a quick funny game and it was probably someone\'s starting project so I can\'t complain too much.  It\'s worth $2.99.  I got it for $1.49 of something a few weeks ago when it was only 50% off.  Anyway, I would recommentd this game to anyone in need of a short funny game to play through.  Try it for yourself before judging the game.
